user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2 is: Language extensions should not be used.
You should report only when the code uses any language compiler extensions that are explicitly stated as an extension in compiler documentations.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of UT_GetStubRetcodeAndCount:
```c
bool UT_GetStubRetcodeAndCount(UT_EntryKey_t FuncKey, int32 *Retcode, int32 *Count)
{
    UT_StubTableEntry_t *StubPtr;
    bool                 Result;

    StubPtr = UT_GetStubEntry(FuncKey, UT_ENTRYTYPE_COUNTER);
    if (StubPtr != NULL)
    {
        *Count   = StubPtr->Data.Rc.Count;
        *Retcode = StubPtr->Data.Rc.Value;
        Result   = true;
    }
    else
    {
        Result = false;
    }

    return Result;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function UT_GetStubRetcodeAndCount:
typedef cpuaddr UT_EntryKey_t
...
typedef int32_t   int32
...
typedef struct
{
    UT_EntryType_t EntryType;
    uint32         ModeFlags;
    UT_EntryKey_t  FuncKey;
    UT_EntryData_t Data;
} UT_StubTableEntry_t
...
static UT_StubTableEntry_t *UT_GetStubEntry(UT_EntryKey_t FuncKey, UT_EntryType_t TestMode)
{
    UT_StubTableEntry_t *StubPtr   = NULL;
    uint32               Idx       = FuncKey % (UT_MAX_FUNC_STUBS - 1); /* hash the key to determine the start point */
    uint32               SearchLen = 0;
    uint32               SearchLimit;
    UT_EntryKey_t        SearchKey;

    /* If searching for an unused entry, look through the entire table.
     * Otherwise bound the search */
    if (TestMode == UT_ENTRYTYPE_UNUSED)
    {
        SearchLimit = UT_MAX_FUNC_STUBS;
        SearchKey   = 0;
    }
    else
    {
        SearchLimit = UT_MaxStubSearchLen;
        SearchKey   = FuncKey;
    }

    while (1)
    {
        if (SearchLen >= SearchLimit)
        {
            StubPtr = NULL;
            break;
        }
        ++SearchLen;
        StubPtr = &UT_StubTable[Idx];
        if (StubPtr->EntryType == TestMode && StubPtr->FuncKey == SearchKey)
        {
            break;
        }
        ++Idx;
        if (Idx >= UT_MAX_FUNC_STUBS)
        {
            Idx = 0;
        }
    }

    /*
     * Keep track of the longest search length since the last reset.
     * This serves as the upper bound for future searches.
     */
    if (SearchLen > UT_MaxStubSearchLen)
    {
        UT_MaxStubSearchLen = SearchLen;
    }

    return StubPtr;
}
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: No explicit compiler language extensions are present in the provided code fragments. The constructs used are standard C: function definitions and returns, pointers, structs, typedefs, fixed-width integer types (int32_t), standard arithmetic and control flow (if/else, while, break), increment/decrement, array indexing, and pointer dereference. The use of bool can be implemented as the standard C _Bool / stdbool.h and is not an extension by itself. The identifier cpuaddr appears as a typedef target (typedef cpuaddr UT_EntryKey_t) but this is a type alias declared elsewhere; the snippet does not show any compiler-specific builtin or extension (for example: __asm__, __attribute__, __builtin_*, typeof, pragma extensions, inline assembler, nonstandard storage-class specifiers, or compiler-specific keywords). Because cpuaddr’s underlying definition is not shown, it is not evidence of a language extension in the presented code — it may be a project-defined typedef. Therefore no fragments need to be investigated for Rule 1.2 based on the provided code.
